answers.text: loss of sensation and voluntary motor control

qas.question: What is the initial phantom body pain sensation experienced by people with spinal cord damage?
The sensation of a knife twisting in the flesh is an example of what type of pain?
What is an inefficient treatment for chronic pain which rarely provides any sort of true relief?
What is the loss of voluntary sensation?
How is phantom spinal pain initially described?

context: <b5_0>Paraplegia<b5_0/>, the <a0_0>loss of sensation and voluntary motor control<a0_0/> after <a1_0>serious spinal cord damage,<a1_0/> may be accompanied by girdle pain at the level of the spinal cord damage, visceral pain evoked by a filling bladder or bowel, or, in five to ten per cent of paraplegics, phantom body pain in areas of complete sensory loss. This <a3_0>phantom body<a3_0/> pain is initially described as <a2_0><b6_0>burning or tingling<b6_0/><a2_0/> but may evolve into severe crushing or pinching pain, or the sensation of fire running down the legs or of a knife twisting in the flesh. Onset may be immediate or may not occur until years after the disabling injury. <a4_0><b7_0>Surgical<a4_0/> treatment<b7_0/> rarely provides lasting relief.
